post.title: Imelda cited in release of almost 100,000 pounds of air pollutants

children.text: As Imelda dumped as many as 43 inches of rain across the Houston region, leading to what the Houston Chronicle reported as "unauthorized releases [of chemicals] ... triggered by electrical outages, the failure of floating roof tanks and equipment malfunctions caused by flooding," companies reported "nearly 100,000 pounds of toxins, including cancer-causing 1,3 butadiene, benzene and ethylene oxide" entering our air.

As Imelda dumped as many as 43 inches of rain across the Houston region, leading to what the Houston Chronicle reports as "unauthorized releases [of chemicals] ... triggered by electrical outages, the failure of floating roof tanks and equipment malfunctions caused by flooding," companies reported "nearly 100,000 pounds of toxins, including cancer-causing 1,3 butadiene, benzene and ethylene oxide" entering our air.

Though the TCEQ said it had not "seen any air emissions of concern," it asked Gov. Greg Abbott again to suspend environmental regulations, as it had for seven months after Hurricane Harvey.
